captions.text:
So a bunch of scientists from a company called
Carbon 3d just introduced a totally new kind

of 3d printing. They were actually inspired
to make it from the movie Terminator 2. Conventional

3d printing involves a printing head that
passes over and over across a platform, depositing

a thin layer of material each time. And this
3d printing, forms an object continuously

out of a liquid resin. So what's happening
here is you have a bath of liquid resin that

solidifies when light hits it. The platform
dips into this resin, and as it rises up,

you have a projector underneath the resin
pool that's projecting a series of cross sectional

images that are in the exact shape of the
object you want to make. So as the platform

slowly moves upwards, the projector moves
through the different images, the different

cross-sections, and that causes the object
to form in the shape you want. Wherever there's

ultra-violet light hitting it, that's where
the plastic solidifies. So this could be a

big deal because it's a lot faster than conventional
3d printers. It works in minutes instead of

hours. Right now 3d printing is still kind
of a niche industry. People use it to make

models or prototypes, but if this new 3d printer
can be perfected, it could be possible for
it to be used to make mass produced goods.

title: This new type of 3D printing was inspired by Terminator 2

make their infinity figures.
What a time to be alive.﻿

comments.text:
In the video, you compare the timing of a tiny Eiffel Tower to a giant 3D 
print from another printer. In actuality, the resin printers are not much 
faster at all and the final product is MUCH more fragile. On the other 
hand, the resin printers can get much finer details.﻿

comments.author: Ghost Emblem

comments.text:
"BrasilUPclose"27MAR2015/Video/Article-English/Blip-English-Português/ 
3D PERSONAL PRINTER II: The new "Carbon3D Personal Printer" is 1000 times 
faster than the other models.
Were you intrigued with the lazer build up 3D Personal Printers shown in my 
previous post? Check out the newest development in 3D printing technology.
This new revolutionary method called Continuous Liquid Interface Production 
(CLIP), builds objects in minutes, without layers, and allows the use of 
many types of materials. ///

IMPRESSORAS PESSOAIS 3D - II: As novas Impressoras Pessoais "Carbon3D" sao 
1000 vezes mais rápidas do que os outros modelos.
Você ficou intrigado com as Impressoras Pessoais 3D a lazer, que mostrei no 
meu post anterior? Verifique este avanço na tecnologia de impressão 3 
dimensional.
Este novo método revolucionário, chamado Continuous Liquid Interface 
Production (CLIP) , constrói objetos sem as camadas sobrepostas - 
produzindo items de mais alta qualidade, e permite o uso de vários tipos de 
materiais.///
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
#Carbon3DPrinter   , #Impressoras3D   , #NewestDevelopment   , #HighTech   
, #Tecnologia   , #Technology   , #TEDConference   , #TED   ,  
#ImpressorasPessoais3D   , #Printers   , #1000Timesfaster  

=======================================
Original Source Article: Architectural Digest / Carbon3D Printers /

LAYERLESS 3D PRINTING = CARBON 3D Personal Printer

At last week’s TED Conference in Vancouver, Carbon3D revealed a new method 
of 3-D printing that can produce objects up to 100 times faster than the 
current technology. Today, most 3-D printers function similarly to standard 
office printers. Both produce superthin layers of material, but instead of 
ejecting an ink-covered sheet of paper, 3-D machines print on top of each 
layer over and over again until an object is formed. As such, 3-D printing 
is an extraordinarily time-consuming process. But Carbon3D’s technology 
avoids the layering procedure, speeding up the print time significantly.

Carbon3D employs a photochemical technology called Continuous Liquid 
Interface Production (CLIP), which pulls solid objects from a pool of 
liquid resin. Essentially, cross-sections of 3-D renderings are placed into 
the resin like a reverse MRI; CLIP then uses UV light to alter the 
structure of the resin and oxygen to halt the changes. The result is a 
quick, seamless production of a 3-D object, more akin to injection-molding 
than printing.

Speed isn’t the only benefit to CLIP. The method produces objects with 
consistent mechanical qualities—which is an issue for layer-based 
printing—and allows for a broader range of materials. With all these 
advancements, Carbon3D’s CLIP technology may be a new revolution in the 
already-revolutionary world of 3-D printing.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 https://youtu.be/l3TgmvV2ElQ
---------------------------------------------------------------------------﻿

comments.text:
After doing a little research this machine looks strikingly similar to DLP 
Lithography which has been around for a long time. The only real difference 
is the CLIP technology that prevents the cured layer from contacting the 
bottom of the tray which is great but still it's not like this is 'brand 
new' technology.﻿

comments.author: Lindsay Butler

comments.text:
The speed is amazing but the resolution is not so sure.  The rail on the 
Eiffel tower is gone.  Not sure if the fine struts below the rail survives. 
 SLA can do much better than this but needs 2 hours.  Using liquid 
photoresin resin for medium to low resolution printing is very expensive.   
Surface quality should be better than normal SLA when printing with thicker 
layers. This will not be a low cost consumer type of product.  It will at 
least start from a few thousand dollars.   ﻿

and made that same piece, that would be a more accurate time frame. ﻿
